Available online 20 July 2025 Article Efficient synthesis of flexible SCR catalysts utilizing graphene oxide as a bridging agent without calcination: Catalytic performance, mechanism and kinetics studies Tingkai Xiong a Fengyu Gao a b * Jiajun Wen a Honghong Yi a b Shunzheng Zhao a b Xiaolong Tang a b * a School of Energy and Environmental Engineering, University of Science & Technology Beijing, Beijing 100083, China School of Energy and Environmental Engineering University of Science & Technology Beijing Beijing 100083 China School of Energy and Environmental Engineering, University of Science & Technology Beijing, Beijing 100083, China b Beijing Key Laboratory of Resource-oriented Treatment of Industrial Pollutants, Beijing 100083, China Beijing Key Laboratory of Resource-oriented Treatment of Industrial Pollutants Beijing 100083 China Beijing Key Laboratory of Resource-oriented Treatment of Industrial Pollutants, Beijing 100083, China * Corresponding author The mechanical performance of flexible catalysts remains a significant challenge for industrial applications. In this study, graphene oxide (GO) functions as both a binder and a redox mediator, serving as a crucial “bridge” between metal species and the organic foam, thereby substantially enhancing NO x conversion efficiency. Catalytic activity tests demonstrate that the GO-modified MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalyst achieves a NO x conversion rate exceeding 95%. The incorporation of GO strengthens the adhesion between the organic foam and metal components, increases the surface roughness of the sponge, and ensures the uniform and stable distribution of metal active sites. Additionally, GO enhances the content of effective catalytic species, improves electron transfer efficiency in the selective catalytic reduction reaction, and reduces diffusion resistance. To elucidate the NO reduction mechanism, in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy and transient reaction studies were performed. The results indicate that as the reaction temperature increases, both the Eley-Rideal and Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanisms contribute to promoting the SCR reaction rate. Graphical Abstract Graphene oxide (GO) significantly enhances the mechanical integrity and electron transfer capability of flexible MnCo catalysts based on melamine sponges, enabling high catalytic efficiency, thermal stability, and resistance to deactivation. Keywords Flexible materials Selective catalytic reduction by NH3 Graphene oxide Redox mediator Kinetics studies 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NO x ) constitute a major component of industrial exhaust emissions, contributing significantly to environmental issues such as acid rain and photochemical pollution. The selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO x using NH3 stands as the predominant technology for NO x abatement, employing various catalysts to enhance its efficiency [ 1,2 ]. Traditional metal catalysts are supported on flexible carriers, offering excellent catalytic activity, along with attributes like reversible deformation and a large specific surface area [ 3,4 ]. However, these metal catalysts often require high-temperature calcination [ 5,6 ], which can cause structural degradation and framework damage to flexible supports. Melamine sponge (MS) has garnered significant attention as a catalyst support due to its lightweight nature, high porosity, scalability, and open-network structure with micron-sized pores and high nitrogen content [ 7–9 ]. Mn-based catalysts have garnered significant attention owing to their remarkable low-temperature catalytic activity and environmentally friendly properties [ 10,11 ]. It has been demonstrated that Mn elements exhibit superior low-temperature activity due to their variable valence and strong redox capacity [ 12 ]. The stability of the catalyst and its resistance to water and sulfur can be enhanced by doping with polymetallic active components such as Ce [ 13 ], Cu [ 14 ], Co [ 15 ], and Fe [ 16 ]. In a previous study, we developed the MnCo bimetallic active center-loaded carbonized melamine sponge SCR catalyst [ 17 ]. The results indicated that the carbonization process converted the organic sponge into carbon sponge, thereby enhancing the adhesion of the metal active component and addressing issues like the challenge of directly growing the metal active center on the organic sponge surface. Nevertheless, the high-temperature calcination would lead to varying degrees of damage to its structure. Organic sponge containing metal active components typically adhere to metal oxide surfaces through surface functional groups [ 18 ] or establish coordination bonds with metal ions [ 19,20 ]. MS often require modification due to their weak interfacial bonding with metal active components [ 8,21 ]. Graphene oxide (GO) is frequently employed as an exceptional catalyst material owing to its extensive specific surface area and unique electronic properties [ 22 ]. GO-modified melamine sponge eliminates the need for high-temperature carbonization and prevents the irreversible aggregation of metal active components, thereby addressing issues such as catalyst shedding and poor reusability. Additionally, it simplifies the fabrication process while maintaining high NO x removal efficiency. The loose and porous structure of the sponge, combined with its excellent resilience, facilitates convenient processing and loading as a catalyst, making it well-suited for complex operational environments. The melamine sponge was modified through the introduction of two-dimensional GO nanosheets to enhance its binding with inorganic catalysts, facilitate electron transfer within the material [ 23 ], and increase the loading of metal oxides. In this study, MnCo-MS@GO catalysts were synthesized via the impregnation method, utilizing a graphene oxide-modified melamine sponge as a carrier and loaded with MnCo bimetal. This preparation method, devoid of high-temperature pretreatment and calcination, was employed to offer insights into the development of an environmentally friendly and efficient approach for the fabrication of flexible catalysts. Additionally, the catalysts were characterized, and the intrinsic relationships between the reaction mechanism, reaction rate, reactant concentration, and catalytic activity were analyzed and investigated through steady-state kinetics. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material synthesis 2.1.1 Synthesis of graphene oxide The synthesis of graphene oxide involved a modified Hummers method [ 24 ]. Initially, 5 g of graphite powder and 3 g of sodium nitrate were precisely measured and placed into a 1 L beaker. Then, 120 mL of concentrated H2SO4 was added to the beaker and followed stirred for 30 minutes under ice bath conditions. Subsequently, 20 g of KMnO4 was gradually introduced into the beaker under low-temperature conditions, and the mixture was stirred at 35 °C for 3 h. Afterward, 600 mL of deionized water was slowly added to the beaker while maintaining an ice bath. Once the addition of deionized water was complete, the mixture was transferred to a water bath set at 95 °C and stirred for 1 h. The temperature was then lowered to 60 °C, and 15 mL of 30% H2O2 was gradually added, allowing the temperature to decrease to room temperature. Following this, the mixture underwent centrifugation, washing with deionized water until reaching neutrality, and finally freeze-drying. 2.1.2 Synthesis of MS@GO Initially, graphene oxide underwent sonication and was dispersed in distilled water to generate a homogeneous graphene oxide suspension. Following this, a melamine sponge measuring 1 × 1 × 1 cm3 was completely immersed in the GO suspension while undergoing sonication for 10 min. Subsequently, the sponge was extracted from the suspension and left to air dry at room temperature, leading to the formation of MS@GO. 2.1.3 Synthesis of MnCo-MS@GO (Scheme 1) A certain mass of KMnO4, Co(NO3)2·6H2O (Mn:Co = 1:2) was dissolved in deionized water, corresponding to a 30% loading of the sponge sample mass, heated to 110 °C for 8 h and dried overnight. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The morphology and structure of the catalysts were observed by scanning electron microscope (SEM, S-4800). The crystallinity of the samples was recorded by X-ray diffraction (XRD, BRUCKER D8) with Cu Kα radiation, and the data were collected in the 2θ range of 20°–80°. The Raman spectra were collected by Raman spectrometer with a laser at 514 nm. The data of the binding energies of Mn 2p, Co 2p, O 1s, and C 1s were obtained by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, PHI 5500) with Al-Kα radiation, referencing the C 1s peak at 284.6 eV. The Fourier transformed infrared (FT-IR) spectra of the powder samples were collected by FT-IR spectroscopy (Thermo IS50). Before the test, background spectra were recorded with KBr powder. Compression cycle testing is performed by an electronic universal testing machine (CMT6103). 2.3 Catalyst activity tests The activity evaluation was carried out in a self-made fixed-bed quartz reactor using a piece of catalyst (length, width, and height are 10, 10, and 10 mm, respectively). The WHSV were 2500 h–1. The reactant gas typically consisted of 500 × 10–6 NO, 500 × 10–6 NH3, 5 vol% O2, and balance N2. 10 vol% H2O was introduced into the reaction system to evaluate the catalyst's water resistance. 10 vol% H2O steam utilizes N2 introduced into the reaction gas through the aqueous phase being heated. 100 × 10–6 SO2 was introduced to evaluate the catalyst's sulfur resistance. The concentrations of NO x and NH3 were tested by an Infrared spectrometer (Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS5). The NO x conversion and N2 selectivity were calculated using Eqs. (1) and (2): (1) No x conversion ( % ) = [ NO x ] in - [ NO x ] out [ NO x ] in × 100 where [NO x ] = [NO] + [NO2] (2) N 2 selectivity ( % ) = ( 1 - 2 × [ N 2 O ] out [ NO x ] in + [ NH 3 ] in - [ NO x ] out - [ NH 3 ] our ) × 100 Assuming that the reaction components are not restricted by diffusion, the reaction rate can be calculated according to Eq. (3): (3) Rate constant k ( cm 3 min - 1 g - 1 ) = - F 0 W × χ × I n ( 1 - X ) where X is the NO x conversion, F 0 is the volumetric flow rate of NO x (mL min–1), W is the weight of the catalyst (g), and x is Mn-Co loads. The apparent activation energy was calculated by Arrhenius’ law. (4) TOF = F 0 22.4 × W × ( χ ( M n ) M Mn + χ ( Co ) M Co ) × X where F 0 is the flow rate of NO x (0.1 mL min–1), W is the catalyst mass (g), x(Mn) and x(Co) is the Mn and Co loading calculated using the XPS data (%), M Mn and M Co is the molar mass of Mn and Co (54.9 and 58.9 g mol–1), respectively. X is the NO x conversion (%). To avoid diffuse effects, NO x conversion should be less than 15%. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance Fig. 1(a) illustrated the catalytic performance of MnCo-MS@GO with varying graphene loadings for NH3-SCR reflection. Melamine sponge catalysts underwent modification with graphene loadings of 0.02, 0.05, 0.08, and 0.10 g cm–3, respectively. It is evident that all catalysts demonstrated a progressive increase in NO x conversion with rising reaction temperature. Optimal NO x conversion was achieved at a reaction temperature of 220 °C. Among them, the catalyst modified with 0.05 g cm–3 graphene exhibited the highest effectiveness, achieving a remarkable NO x conversion rate of up to 98%. The utilization of low-density sponge supports significantly reduces the overall reactor load, thereby improving the energy efficiency of the catalytic reaction system. Due to their low mass, the mass-based reaction rate more accurately reflects the actual efficiency of the catalyst, avoiding dilution effects caused by high mass or volume. The three-dimensional porous structure of flexible sponges greatly enhances gas mass transfer efficiency during the SCR reaction, ensuring sufficient contact and reaction between NO x and NH3. Catalysts with a large specific surface area are better evaluated using mass-based reaction rates, as their activity is predominantly governed by surface reactions. In this study, we assessed catalytic performance by calculating the mass-based reaction rate, with MnCO-MS@0.05GO achieving an impressive rate of 19.2 cm3 min–1 g–1, far surpassing the rates reported for existing catalysts (Fig. S1). However, catalytic activity declined with excessive or insufficient graphene loading. Fig. 1(b) shows that within the reaction temperature range of 50–240 °C, the MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalyst exhibits the best N2 selectivity, consistently exceeding 70%. NH3 serves as the primary reductant for NO x reduction, achieving efficient NO x conversion through standard SCR (4NH3 + 4NO + O2 → 4N2 + 6H2O) or fast SCR (2NH3 + NO + NO2 → 2N2 + 3H2O), which enhances NO x removal efficiency. Partial NH3 oxidation may generate a small amount of NO2, which can facilitate NO x removal in the fast SCR process (as an optimal NO/NO2 ratio of 1:1 is beneficial for fast SCR reactions). However, excessive NH3 oxidation consumes NH3, reduces NO x removal efficiency, and increases the formation of undesired byproducts such as NO or N2O. An ideal catalyst should regulate NH3 oxidation capacity to ensure that NH3 primarily participates in the SCR reaction rather than undergoing non-selective oxidation. MnCo-MS@0.05GO exhibits high NO x removal efficiency within the temperature range of 150–250 °C (Fig. 1(c)), indicating excellent NH3 conversion. The apparent activation energy (E a) of NH3-SCR was derived from the curve slope, with MnCo-MS@0.05GO exhibiting the lowest activation energy (Fig. 1(d)). These findings underscore the significance of optimizing graphene loading to diminish the reaction's energy barrier and enhance catalytic performance. Identification of the optimal graphene loading was based on changes in catalytic activity, with both excellent redox properties and high dispersion of active components identified as pivotal factors contributing to the superior catalytic activity of MnCo-MS@GO. As depicted in Fig. 1(e), the NH3-SCR performance of MnCo-MS, MS@0.05GO, and MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalysts was investigated over a temperature range of 50 to 240 °C. The MS@0.05GO catalyst demonstrated no catalytic activity within this temperature window. In contrast, the MnCo-MS catalyst, which was not subjected to calcination, achieved a maximum rate constant κ of only 1.43 cm3 min–1 g–1), corresponding to a NO x conversion rate of merely 29%. Turnover frequency (TOF) measures the rate at which a catalyst facilitates a reaction. For a more accurate comparison, TOF calculations should be based on the initial reaction rate within the kinetic range, ensuring the reaction rate is influenced solely by the number of active sites and not by diffusion [ 25 ]. When comparing the TOF values of MnCo-MS and MnCo-MS@0.05GO, it was found that the TOF value for MnCo-MS@0.05GO was significantly higher in the temperature range of 60–90 °C (Fig. 1(f)). This suggests that MnCo-MS@0.05GO has a greater number of active centers than MnCo-MS and stronger catalytic capacity of the metal active component. The rich oxygen-containing groups on the surface of GO provide abundant loading sites, which enhance the dispersion of active components and prevent metal agglomeration [ 26 ]. The graphene oxide plays a significant auxiliary role in enhancing catalytic activity, although it does not directly participate in the reaction. In the NH3-SCR reaction, an increase in the specific surface area facilitates the exposure of active sites, thereby enhancing NO x adsorption and promoting the catalytic reaction. However, an excessively high specific surface area may lead to the collapse of the pore structure or a decrease in the dispersion of active components, ultimately affecting catalytic performance. The catalyst exhibits the highest specific surface area at GO loading of 0.5 g cm–3 (Table S2). This phenomenon may be attributed to insufficient GO dispersion at lower loadings, which fails to effectively improve the pore structure of the melamine sponge. Additionally, Mn and Co active species may undergo agglomeration, resulting in a reduced specific surface area and inadequate exposure of active sites. Conversely, at higher GO loadings, the layered structure of graphene can lead to pore blockage, thereby decreasing the specific surface area and hindering the diffusion of reactants into the catalyst, leading to diminished catalytic activity. Under actual operating conditions, flue gas typically contains H2O [ 27,28 ] and SO2 [ 29–31 ], which significantly impact the catalyst's ability to remove NO x . The presence of H2O vapor notably affects the SCR activity of Mn-based catalysts, primarily due to the loss of active centers on the catalyst surface [ 32 ]. Fig. 2(a) illustrated the changes in catalytic activity for the MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalyst in the presence of 10 vol% H2O. The rate constant k of the catalyst decreased from 14.6 to 9.4 cm3 min–1 g–1 and NO x conversion decreased from 97% to 89% with the introduction of H2O. However, once the H2O introduction was halted, the catalytic activity resumed to its initial levels. SO2 also exerts a significant inhibitory effect on catalytic performance, often causing permanent deactivation of the catalyst. The SO2 tolerance test (Fig. 2(b)) revealed that the decrease in catalyst activity after the introduction of 100 × 10–6 of SO2. The effect of SO2 on the catalyst appears to be irreversible, likely due to interactions with surface oxygen-containing functional groups [ 33 ]. Throughout the testing process, the MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalyst demonstrated the best resistance to both water and sulfur, maintaining superior performance under these challenging conditions. The deactivation effect of SO2 on MnCo-MS and MnCo-MS@0.05GO is primarily attributed to sulfate formation, which blocks active sites and alters the surface acidity. Both catalysts exhibit a decline in NO conversion upon SO2 exposure. we have conducted TG analysis to examine the thermal decomposition behavior of both fresh and sulfur-poisoned catalysts (Fig. 2(h)), providing insights into the sulfate formation and its impact on the catalytic performance. As the catalyst is exposed to air, its surface may adsorb a certain amount of water molecules. These water molecules interact with the catalyst through hydrogen bonding or van der Waals forces and can be easily desorbed at low temperatures. Some water molecules may also form hydrogen bonds or weak chemical bonds with metal oxides or functional groups on the catalyst, requiring a higher temperature (100–200 °C) for desorption. The sulfur-poisoned catalyst exhibits less mass loss at this stage, likely due to the adsorption of SO2 or other sulfur oxides, which reduces the hydrophilicity of the catalyst surface and decreases water adsorption. When the temperature reaches 400 °C, the catalyst undergoes a noticeable mass loss, mainly due to the decomposition of surface organic functional groups and ammonium sulfate species. Melamine sponge contains a large number of nitrogen-containing organic groups (–NH2, –NH–, C=N, etc.), which may decompose in this temperature range, generating small organic molecules such as NH3 and HCN [ 17 ]. The results indicate the thermal stability of the MnCo-MS@GO system under reaction conditions. Below 400 °C, the observed weight loss is primarily attributed to the evaporation of residual moisture and small molecular formaldehyde from the sponge material. The gradual weight decrease suggests that the skeletal structure of the sponge is breaking down at a slow rate. At 500 °C, the total mass loss of the sulfur-poisoned catalyst reaches 9.41%, while the mass loss of the original catalyst is 7.48%. This difference may be related to the decomposition of metal sulfates, as indicated by a significant mass loss peak observed in the DTG curve near 500 °C (Fig. 2(i)). As the temperature continues to rise, the sulfur-poisoned catalyst consistently exhibits a higher mass loss rate than the non-poisoned catalyst, suggesting that the formation and decomposition of sulfate species significantly impact the thermal stability of the catalyst [ 28 ]. This indicates that the decomposition of metal sulfates is the primary factor contributing to the increased mass loss. Due to the enrichment of more SO4 2– species on the surface of the sulfur-poisoned catalyst, it shows a higher mass loss rate at this stage. Deposition of metal sulphates is also one of the main causes of irreversible catalyst deactivation. Fig. 2(c) illustrated the change in catalytic activity of the MnCo-MS@GO catalyst in the presence of 10 vol% H2O and 100 × 10–6 SO2. Following exposure to SO2 and H2O, there was a noticeable decrease in catalytic activity. Upon removal of SO2 and H2O, the catalytic activity partially recovered; however, it did not return to its initial level. This incomplete recovery suggests that SO2 poisoning may have caused a slight permanent reduction in catalytic activity. Fig. 2(d) presents the stability test results for the MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalyst. The data indicate that the conversion rate of the catalyst remains almost unaffected after continuous operation for over 48 h. This stability suggests that the MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalyst maintains consistent catalytic performance under these working conditions, implying a longer service life. Consequently, this stability enhances its suitability for practical applications, making it a more reliable option for industrial use. The recyclability of traditional rigid catalysts is often limited by cumbersome regeneration processes. In this study, we define a flexible catalyst as a mechanically robust, compressible, and deformable catalytic material that maintains structural integrity and catalytic performance under dynamic conditions. Unlike conventional rigid catalysts, MnCo-MS@GO catalyst is based on a flexible melamine sponge (MS) framework, which provides excellent mechanical resilience and adaptability while ensuring uniform dispersion of active sites. Compression cycling properties are one of the important evaluation indexes for flexible materials. Integrated flexible catalysts provide an effective alternative by addressing the drawbacks of particle-shaped catalysts, such as high pressure loss and elevated costs, while maintaining efficient catalytic performance. Our study on the recyclability of MnCo-MS@0.05GO revealed that the catalyst retains an impressive rate constant κ of 9.5 cm3 min–1 g–1 (corresponding to 90% NO x conversion) even after five cycles of use, demonstrating its excellent durability and potential for repeated applications (Fig. 2(e)). The flexibility of the catalyst was further evaluated through compression cycle tests, which are critical for studying mechanical performance and practical application potential. These tests simulate the mechanical deformation that catalysts may endure under real-world operating conditions and assess their ability to maintain performance. As shown in Fig. 2(f), after 1, 3, and 5 cycles of usage, the catalyst maintained structural integrity under 60% compressive strain, although a slight reduction in compressive yield strain was observed (Fig. 2(g)). Compressive yield strain refers to the strain value at the transition from elastic deformation to plastic deformation on the compressive stress-strain curve, corresponding to the yield point. A high yield strain indicates that the support structure remains largely intact during compression, contributing to the stable distribution of active components and thereby sustaining catalytic performance. The observed decrease in compressive yield strain is one of the primary factors contributing to fluctuations in catalytic performance. In summary, GO modification enabled MnCo bimetallic catalysts to exhibit high SCR catalytic activity and N2 selectivity without the need for high-temperature calcination. The MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalyst demonstrated the highest TOF value and the lowest activation energy during the SCR reaction process. Additionally, it showed excellent stability and resistance to both water and sulfur. Future research would focus on a series of characterizations to further investigate the relationship between MnCo MS and MnCo-MS@0.05GO, specifically examining the positive role of GO in catalyst preparation. 3.2 Structure properties 3.2.1 SEM characterizations of the catalysts The morphological characteristics of MnCo-MS, MS@0.05GO, and MnCo-MS@GO were examined via scanning electron microscopy (Fig. 3 ). The melamine sponge exhibits a reticulated structure with interconnected pores ranging from tens to hundreds of micrometers, which are crucial for internal mass transfer and circulation. However, its smooth skeleton surface promotes metal aggregation at reticular junctions, hindering the uniform dispersion of metal active components. Morphological characterization of MS@0.05GO reveals uniform loading of graphene onto the melamine sponge skeleton in a lamellar structure. The porous structure of the melamine sponge remained intact, albeit with significantly increased surface roughness, and the appearance of micro- and nano-scale protrusions and folds on the skeleton. This phenomenon is attributed to the thin coating of graphene, confirming its deposition on the sponge skeleton's surface. The interaction force between GO changed from electrostatic repulsion to π–π bonding force, guiding flake graphene loading around the sponge skeleton. When graphene interacts with a metal, there is typically a high density of electronic states on the metal surface, facilitating the formation of covalent bonds with the π-electron orbitals of graphene, thereby enhancing the bonding between graphene and the metal [ 34 ]. Moreover, van der Waals forces can further bolster the binding force between graphene and the metal [ 35 ]. The introduction of flake graphene oxide improves the uniform distribution of metal active components on the melamine sponge, driven by modified interaction forces and increased surface roughness [ 36 ]. SEM element mapping was conducted to analyze the surface element distribution of the samples, namely MnCo-MS, MS@GO, and MnCo-MS@GO (Fig. 4 ). Carbon (C), nitrogen (N), and oxygen (O) elements were found to be uniformly distributed on the sponge skeleton across all samples. However, Mn and Co exhibited significant aggregation in MnCo-MS, whereas their distribution in MnCo-MS@0.05GO was more uniform. Metal aggregation can lead to a decrease in surface active sites, as larger metal particles have a relatively small specific surface area and provide fewer active sites. This directly reduces the activity of the catalyst. In contrast, enhanced metal dispersion provides more active sites, improving catalytic performance. Choosing GO with its high specific surface area and good interaction properties as the carrier material improves the dispersion and binding force of the metal in the catalyst and alters the surface properties. Therefore, using GO as a binder is of great significance for achieving uniform distribution of metal active components. Therefore, the modification with GO not only prevents metal aggregation but also enhances the distribution of active sites, thereby improving the overall catalytic activity and stability of the MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalyst. This highlights the critical role of GO in the preparation of high-performance catalysts. From the line scan and energy spectrum of Figs. 4(m) and 4(n), it can be observed that the uniformly dispersed particles in the catalyst mainly consist of Mn, Co, and O elements, possibly forming MnO x , CoO x , or some heterogeneous junction or cluster structure, as reflected in the XRD analysis. The consistent distribution of Mn, Co, and O confirms the homogeneous integration of Co and Mn, a key factor in the catalyst's high activity. Meanwhile, C and N, as the main components of the catalyst support, play a critical role in ensuring the dispersion of the catalyst. GO significantly improves the interfacial adhesion between metal species (Mn, Co) and the flexible melamine sponge, preventing metal particle agglomeration and detachment. SEM images reveal that the pristine melamine sponge has a smooth surface, making it difficult for catalytic active components to adhere firmly. However, after modification, the layered structure of GO wraps around the melamine sponge, increasing surface roughness and greatly enhancing metal particle attachment. Additionally, when GO interacts with metal species, the high electron density on the metal surface facilitates covalent bonding with the π-electron orbitals of GO. This strengthens the metal-GO interaction, improving both metal adhesion and the overall structural stability of the catalyst. 3.2.2 Raman test Raman spectroscopy was employed for further analysis of MS, GO, MS@GO, and MnCo-MS@0.05GO (Fig. 5(a) ). The vibration of the triazine ring, observed around 978 cm–1, was present in both MS@0.05GO and MnCo-MS@0.05GO [ 17 ]. Additionally, MnCo-MS@0.05GO exhibited a peak of Mn-O at 659 cm–1. Characteristic peaks at positions 1355 and 1585 cm–1, attributed to the loading of GO, resulted in the D/G peak of carbon atomic crystals [ 37 ]. The D peak primarily arises from the stretching vibration of C–C and C=C bonds, reflecting the material's structure and defect status, while the G peak mainly stems from the stretching vibration of SP2 hybridized carbon atoms and π electrons [ 38,39 ]. Therefore, the ratio of D/G peaks can represent the degree of defect and graphitization in carbon atomic crystals (Table 1 ). The ratio of the D peak to the G peak in graphene is a crucial parameter for assessing its degree of graphitization and defect density. The analysis revealed that the D/G ratio of GO and MS@0.05GO did not exhibit significant differences and remained unchanged. However, upon loading with metal active components, the MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalyst showed an increase in graphitization degree. This enhancement enables the π electron cloud within the material to move more freely within a two-dimensional plane, consequently promoting electron transfer [ 40 ]. The efficiency of electron transfer directly influences the reaction rate and overall performance, indicating improved electron transfer and robust chemical interaction between GO and metal active component. The microscopic morphology of GO and metal active components on the melamine sponge was examined using SEM. To further investigate the correlation between Raman spectral characteristics in different regions and understand the spatial distribution of various components within the sample, Raman mapping was performed on the MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalyst. The analysis focused on spectral peaks at 659, 1355, and 1585 cm–1. The results indicated a relatively uniform distribution of graphene and metal active components, highlighting the critical role of GO modification in achieving homogeneous dispersion of metallic active sites. 3.2.3 XRD patterns XRD analysis was conducted to detect the crystal structure of MnCo-MS and MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalysts (Fig. 5(b)). MnCo-MS@0.05GO exhibited a distinct diffraction peak near 11°, which is a characteristic peak of GO [ 41 ]. In comparison, the characteristic peak of the catalyst in MnCo-MS@0.05GO was not as sharp as that of MnCo-MS. Moreover, it was observed that metal oxides in MnCo-MS@0.05GO were relatively dispersed. Metal ions can adsorb onto the surface of GO sheets through interactions with oxygen-containing functional groups [ 42 ], serving as nucleation sites for metal oxides. Additionally, MnCo-MS@0.05GO contained a substantial amount of MnO2 and Co3O4, one of the key active components in the SCR reaction, consistent with XPS measurement results. 3.2.4 FT-IR spectra FT-IR spectroscopic analysis was conducted on MS, MS@GO, and GO to investigate surface functional groups and demonstrate the role of graphene oxide as a redox mediator in catalyst preparation (Fig. 5(c)). The infrared spectra of the melamine sponge revealed the presence of numerous nitrogen-containing functional groups. Specifically, a triazine ring bending vibrational peak appeared at 813 cm–1, while peaks at 1152 and 1550 cm–1 corresponded to C–N telescopic and C=N telescopic vibrational peaks, respectively [ 17 ]. The N–H telescopic vibrational peak was observed at 3335 cm–1, and the characteristic peak of –CH2– appeared at 2934 cm–1 [ 43 ]. In the GO sample, O–H stretching vibration at 3412 cm–1 and C=C stretching vibration peak at 1627 cm–1 were observed [ 44 ]. Furthermore, the abundance of oxygen–containing functional groups in GO resulted in peaks at 1733 cm–1 (C=O stretching vibration), 1398 cm–1 (C–O stretching vibration of –COOH), and 1101 cm–1 (C–O stretching vibration of C–OH) [ 45 ]. MS@0.05GO and MnCo-MS@0.05GO exhibited most characteristic peaks observed in MS and GO, with some alterations, indicating successful loading of GO onto the melamine sponge and subsequent loading of MnCo onto the graphene-modified melamine sponge. Comparing the infrared spectra of GO and MS@0.05GO, the C–O peak and C–N signal of MS@0.05GO appear weaker. This likely stems from the formation of hydrogen bonds between GO and MS. Simultaneously, the peak intensity corresponding to C=C and the triazine ring in MS@0.05GO diminishes, indicating π–π packing interaction between MS and GO. In the infrared spectrum of MnCo-MS@0.05GO, weaker oxygen-containing functional groups are observed, possibly due to graphene oxide acting as a redox medium during preparation, thereby reducing the content of oxygen-containing functional groups [ 46 ]. The results from SEM, Raman, XRD, and FTIR tests have elucidated the beneficial role of GO modification in facilitating dispersion and bonding between the melamine sponge and metal components. This effect primarily stems from the abundant oxygen-containing functional groups present on the surface of GO, which facilitate strong binding interactions. Consequently, the aggregation of metal components is mitigated, while ensuring a more robust loading of active metal species. Moreover, the Raman and FTIR characterization results suggest that GO modification has the potential to enhance electron transfer capabilities and act as an oxidation-reduction medium. Moving forward, our investigation will delve deeper into the relationship between GO modification and the resulting changes in chemical properties and catalytic activity. 3.2.5 XPS spectra The influence of GO on the MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalyst was further substantiated through XPS analysis of surface chemical composition. Table 2 displays its relative yard concentration. The correlation spectra are charge-corrected relative to the C 1s peak at 284.6 eV (Fig. 6 ) [ 47 ]. The MnCo content in MnCo-MS is higher than that in MnCo-MS@0.05GO, likely due to the aggregation effect, which results in a significant accumulation of metal components on the melamine sponge framework. However, the content of (Mn4++Mn3+) and Co3+ in the MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalyst is substantially higher than that in MnCo-MS, indicating that graphene oxide acts as a redox mediator in the system. Compared to MnCo-MS, MnCo-MS@0.05GO exhibits an elevated carbon content, likely attributable to successful graphene oxide loading on the melamine sponge. The C 1s peak can be segmented into three peaks: C=C (284.6 eV), C–O (286.68 eV), and C=O (288.48 eV), respectively (Fig. 6(a)) [ 48,49 ]. However, unlike MnCo-MS, a characteristic π–π bond peak is evident in MnCo-MS@0.05GO, attributable to GO doping. Additionally, the content of oxygen-containing functional groups sharply decreases in MnCo-MS@0.05GO, indicating the production of MnO x via the redox reaction between KMnO4 and oxygen–containing functional groups. The O 1s spectrum can be segmented into three peaks (Fig. 6(b)), corresponding to adsorbed oxygen Oα (531.8–532.5 eV), lattice oxygen Oβ (529.8–530.1 eV), and oxygen-containing group Oγ (533.9–534.7 eV) [ 50 ]. The proportion of Oα species in MnCo-MS@0.05GO is 77.2%, significantly higher than the adsorbed oxygen content in MnCo-MS material, thereby promoting the SCR reaction [ 51 ]. The Mn 2p spectrum (Fig. 6(c)) reveals two signal peaks of Mn 2p 3/2 and Mn 2p 1/2 around 643 and 654 eV, respectively [ 50 ]. Mn 2p 3/2 can be fitted into three peaks: 641.0 eV corresponds to Mn2+, 642.6 eV to Mn3+, and 645.4 eV to Mn4+. Both Mn2+, Mn3+ and Mn4+ are present in MnCo-MS@0.05GO, consistent with XRD results. Mn4+ is commonly employed as the active component in SCR reactions, while Mn3+ can serve as a reaction intermediate, being both oxidized and reduced during the process. Therefore, a higher (Mn3++Mn4+)/Mn ratio is a key factor for superior SCR activity. Additionally, the Mn peak position in the GO-doped catalyst material shifts towards lower binding energy, indicating that graphene doping alters the binding force between the metal active component and the carrier, thereby modifying the electron density around the Mn atom. Similarly, by fitting the XPS spectrum of Co, three characteristic peaks of Co are evident in MnCo-MS@0.05GO, while MnCo-MS displays only two characteristic peaks (Fig. 6(d)). The intensity of the Co 2p satellite peak is closely related to interfacial effects, particularly during the transition from a 2D to a 3D material structure, where the satellite peak signal may weaken. As a typical 2D layered structure, GO provides abundant active sites, effectively disperses metal active components, and alters their electronic environment. Previous studies have highlighted the beneficial role of Co3+ in enhancing catalytic activity, as it can synergistically participate in the redox process of the catalyst (Co3+ + Mn3+ → Co2+ + Mn4+). Mn typically demonstrates a strong redox capacity, whereas Co exhibits high adsorption capacity and reactivity. This electronic effect can enhance the decomposition of oxygen molecules on the catalyst surface and thereby increase the rate of oxygen vacancy formation [ 52 ]. In MnCo-MS@GO, GO provides a highly dispersed two-dimensional layered structure, ensuring the uniform distribution of metal active components on the support surface. XRD and SEM analyses indicate that Mn and Co are more evenly dispersed on GO, preventing the agglomeration of metal oxide particles observed in MnCo-MS. The high dispersion of metal species offers more accessible active sites, thereby enhancing the TOF value. XPS analysis reveals that the Mn3+/Mn4+ and Co3+ ratios in MnCo-MS@GO are significantly higher than those in MnCo-MS. The introduction of GO acts as an electron-regulating medium, facilitating the Mn3+ Mn4+ redox cycle and improving the oxidation capacity of the catalyst, thereby accelerating the SCR reaction rate. The synergistic effect of Mn3+/Mn4+ and Co3+ enhances NO oxidation capability while optimizing NH3 adsorption and activation processes, ultimately boosting catalytic activity. Therefore, GO modification significantly impacts the valence state of metal active components. FT-IR analysis reveals that the surface of GO is rich in functional groups such as hydroxyl, carboxyl, and epoxy groups, which possess redox activity and can participate in redox reactions. By regulating the content and distribution of these functional groups, GO can effectively control the redox properties and optimize performance in oxidation-reduction reactions. This capability to modulate the surface chemistry is a key factor contributing to the superior catalytic activity of MnCo-MS@0.05GO. 3.2.6 NH3-TPD and H2-TPR NH3-TPD analysis reveals that the weak acid center peak of MnCo-MS@0.05GO (148 °C) remains largely unchanged compared to MnCo-MS (145 °C), whereas the medium-strong acid center peak shifts from 332 to 305 °C (Fig. 7(a) ) [ 4 ]. Peak area calculations indicate that GO modification increases the total number of acid sites, suggesting an enhancement of the acidic environment (Fig. 7(b)). In the medium-strong acid temperature range (200–400 °C), a significant increase in acid site density is observed following GO incorporation. This modification optimizes the catalyst's acidic properties through multiple mechanisms. Firstly, the oxygen-containing functional groups in GO interact with metal active sites, reinforcing the strength of existing acid sites. An increased number of acid sites facilitates more effective NH3 adsorption and activation, thereby accelerating the SCR reaction. Furthermore, GO modification not only enhances acid site density but also reduces the medium-strong acid peak temperature, indicating a shift in acid site strength. Overall, the influence of medium and strong acid centers plays a crucial role in the catalytic reaction performance. Within the tested temperature range, the H2-TPR data primarily reflect the changes in Mn species. The reduction characteristics of the MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalyst are mainly influenced by the behavior of adsorbed oxygen and the reduction of Mn species (Fig. 7(c)). In the 200–220 °C range, the H2 consumption of MnCo-MS@0.05GO is primarily attributed to the reduction of adsorbed oxygen. Adsorbed oxygen (Oads) is generally highly active and plays a crucial role in promoting NO oxidation and NH3 activation in the NH3-SCR reaction, thereby enhancing the low-temperature denitrification performance of the catalyst. The introduction of GO likely increases the quantity of oxygen species on the catalyst surface, leading to higher redox activity at lower temperatures. Additionally, the peak area in the H2-TPR profile directly corresponds to the number of reducible surface species (Fig. 7(d)). Compared to MnCo-MS, MnCo-MS@0.05GO exhibits a higher H2 consumption, with significant reduction peaks observed at 280 and 360 °C, corresponding to the MnO2 → Mn2O3 and Mn2O3 → Mn3O4 reduction processes, respectively [ 26 ]. The greater H2 consumption of MnCo-MS@0.05GO suggests a higher concentration of Mn4+ and Mn3+ species both on the surface and in the bulk phase. These high-valence Mn species serve as key active centers in the NH3-SCR reaction, facilitating the redox cycle (Mn4+/Mn3+/Mn2+) and thereby promoting the SCR process. These findings are consistent with the XPS results, further confirming that the MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalyst exhibits superior redox capability, which is closely associated with its higher Mn4+ and Mn3+ content and the abundance of adsorbed oxygen species. 3.2.7 Electrochemical test Raman spectroscopy reveals that the D/G ratio remains unchanged between GO and MS@0.05GO, indicating that the structural integrity of GO is maintained. However, after incorporating metal active components, the MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalyst exhibits a higher degree of graphitization. This enhancement allows π-electron clouds to move more freely within the 2D plane, facilitating electron transfer. Exploring the microelectronic activity of materials through electrochemical test involves employing electrochemical impedance spectroscopy. This method is commonly utilized to characterize electron transfer at interfaces, with circular arcs in impedance plots representing charge transfer impedance related to the Faraday reaction of the electrode. A smaller arc radius indicates lower charge transfer impedance [ 53,54 ]. The results indicate that MnCo-MS@0.05GO exhibits a smaller arc radius compared to MnCo-MS. Consequently, MnCo-MS@ 0.05GO displays lower charge transfer resistance and faster electron transfer rates (Fig. 8(a) ). Additionally, the material exhibits lower diffusion resistance, facilitating the migration of surface-active species. Comparing the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of MnCo-MS and MnCo-MS@0.05GO, during CV testing, oxidation/reduction reactions on the same electrode occur sequentially over time (Fig. 8(b)). The current-voltage curves during both the positive and negative scan stages of cyclic voltammetry exhibit symmetric shapes, indicating that electron transfer on the surface of both materials involves reversible reactions [ 55 ]. The redox potentials of MnCo-MS@0.05GO are 1.03 V and –0.95 V, respectively, while those of MnCo-MS are 1.35 and –1.17 V, respectively. This suggests that MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalysts exhibit stronger redox activity compared to MnCo-MS. GO possesses excellent conductivity, and π–π* conjugated structure facilitates electron transfer, which is beneficial for promoting redox reactions. During the redox process, GO can act as an electron transfer medium by either providing electrons to or adsorbing electrons from the redox reactants. This capability enhances the efficiency of redox reactions by ensuring a continuous flow of electrons, thereby stabilizing the reaction intermediates and improving the overall catalytic performance. The effective electron transfer channels provided by GO are crucial for the enhanced catalytic activity observed in MnCo-MS@0.05GO, making it an optimal choice for applications requiring high redox activity and stability. In summary, due to the rich surface functional groups and unique electronic structure, GO exhibits excellent electron transfer capabilities. By regulating the content of GO, it is possible to achieve precise control over its physical and chemical properties, thereby optimizing redox reactions. This precise control is a key factor influencing the catalytic activity of MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalysts. 3.3 Reaction mechanism and kinetic calculation 3.3.1 In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) study NH3 or NO+O2 adsorption To explore the effects of different reactants on MnCo-MS@0.05GO, we analyzed the mechanism of action on the catalyst using in situ DRIFTS. When NH3 is present, MnCo-MS@0.05GO forms strong adsorption on NH3 (Figs. 9(a) and (b) ). The peaks at 3323 and 3269 cm–1 correspond to N–H coordinated with NH3 on Lewis acid sites [ 56 ]. Peaks at 1249 and 1141 cm–1 arise from the asymmetric and symmetric bending vibration peaks of coordinated NH3 species adsorbed on Lewis acid sites. The peaks at 1520 and 1744 cm–1 belong to NH2 species and NH4 + formed on Brönsted acid sites [ 4 ]. Ammonia adsorption undergoes oxidation during the reaction process, leading to a peak at 1360 cm–1 corresponding to oxidized species of adsorbed ammonia. As the reaction time increases, the number of adsorbed ammonia species gradually rises. Subsequently, we investigated how MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalyst adsorbs NO+O2 for testing (Figs. 9(c) and (d)). The peak at 1726 cm–1 corresponds to adsorbed NO species [ 47 ]. Due to the generation of NO2 by NO in an oxygen environment, NO2 adsorbed species form at 1611 cm–1. A characteristic peak of bridging nitrate appears at 1545 cm–1. Peaks at 1170 and 1252 cm–1 are attributed to monodentate nitrate and bidentate nitrate, respectively [ 57 ]. It is observed that the absorption peak at 1545 cm–1 fluctuates gradually, indicating an increase in the content of bidentate nitrate. This suggests that NO species are first adsorbed to form bridging nitrates, which are then gradually oxidized to more stable bidentate nitrates. 3.3.2 Reaction between pre-adsorbed NH3 and NO+O2 or pre-adsorbed NO+O2 and NH3 Initially, the sample was treated with 500 × 10–6 NH3 at 180 °C using MnCo-MS@0.05GO for 30 minutes (Figs. 10(a) and (b) ). Subsequently, 500 × 10–6 NO and 5% O2 were introduced into the reaction cell. Following NH3 adsorption, coordinated NH3 species adsorbed on Lewis acid sites and NH4 + species adsorbed on Brönsted acid sites were observed. A distinctive peak of NH2 species emerged at 1540 cm–1. Upon the introduction of NO+O2, the adsorbed ammonia species gradually weakened. Simultaneously, three vibration peaks appeared at 1635, 1522, and 1269 cm–1 [ 58 ]. Among these, the 1635 cm–1 peak corresponds to the adsorption of the SCR reaction product H2O. These results suggest that the adsorbed NH3 can react with gaseous NO, indicative of the Eley-Rideal (E-R) reaction mechanism in SCR reactions. When subjected to pre-treatment with 500 × 10–6 NO and 5% O2, the MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalyst predominantly exists in the form of monodentate nitrate and bidentate nitrate during catalysis. Upon the introduction of NH3, the characteristic peaks of these two species gradually diminish. This observation suggests that the adsorbed NO x reacts with the adsorbed NH3, indicating involvement in the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism within the SCR reaction. As depicted in Fig. 10(c) and (d), it is evident that the adsorbed NH4NO2 (1644 cm–1) decreases at a faster rate compared to NH4NO3 (1508 cm–1) [ 57 ]. These results imply that the reaction rate via the nitrite pathway is accelerated, and the ultimate decomposition product of nitrite is N2, not N2O. 3.3.3 Transient reaction Fig. 11(a) illustrates the effect of NH3 pretreatment on the instantaneous reaction process of NO+O2 over the MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalyst. The NO concentration gradually increases to approximately 470 × 10–6, while the N2O concentration initially rises to about 20 × 10–6 before decreasing to around 10 × 10–6, aligning with the background N2O concentration. This reduction indicates the occurrence of a non-selective catalytic reduction (NSCR) reaction, suggesting that the adsorbed NH3 reacts with gaseous NO via the E-R mechanism at 150 °C, producing N2O. In Fig. 11(b), the effect of NO+O2 pretreatment on the instantaneous reaction process of NH3 over the MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalyst is presented. Initially, the NH3 concentration decreases for the first three minutes, followed by a gradual increase to approximately 490 × 10–6, indicating NH3 adsorption. Simultaneously, the N2O concentration shows a slow increase before gradually decreasing. This trend is attributed to the reaction between the adsorbed NH3 and NO x species via the L-H mechanism, which also produces N2O. The subsequent decrease in N2O concentration to 5 × 10–6 is likely due to NH3 oxidation. 3.4 NH3-SCR reaction mechanism over MnCo-MS@0.05GO 3.4.1 The E-R mechanism and the L-H mechanism In situ infrared results show that MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalyst contributes both L-H mechanism and E-R mechanism to the SCR reaction process, resulting in the formation of N2 and by-product N2O. The reduction reaction of NO by the E-R mechanism can be described as [ 59 ]: (5) NH3(gas) → NH3(ad) (6) Mn4+ = O + NH3(ad) → –NH2 + Mn3+ –OH (7) Mn4+ = O + NH2 → NH + Mn3+ –OH (8) NH2 + NO(gas) → N2 + H2O (9) NH + NO(gas) → N2O + H+ NH3(gas) is adsorbed onto the acid site of the catalyst, forming the coordination state NH3(ad). Subsequently, the active metal components, represented by Mn n+=O, react with NH3(ad) to produce NH2 species. A fraction of the generated NH2 undergoes further oxidation to form NH species. The NH2 and gaseous NO then combine to yield N2 and H2O. Additionally, the interaction between NH and gaseous NO leads to the formation of N2O and H. The L-H mechanism governing the reduction of NO can be elucidated as follows [ 60 ]: (5) NH3(gas) → NH3(ad) (10) NO(gas) → NO(ad) (11) Mn4+=O + NO(ad) → Mn3+–O–NO (12) Mn4+=O + NO(g) + → Mn3+–O–NO2 (13) NH3(ad) + Mn3+–O–NO → Mn3+–O–NO–NH3 → Mn3+–OH + N2 + H2O (14) NH3(ad) + Mn3+–O–NO2 → Mn3+–O–NO2–NH3 → Mn3+–OH + N2O + H2O (15) Mn3+–OH + → Mn4+=O + NH3(gas) is adsorbed at Brönsted and Lewis acid sites, leading to the formation of NH3(ad) and a spectrum of ammonia species. NO(gas) is physically adsorbed onto the catalyst, resulting in the formation of Mn3+–O–NO and Mn3+–O–NO2 species in the presence of metal active components. Subsequently, NO reacts further to form Mn3+–O–NO–NH3 and Mn3+–O–NO2–NH3 complexes with adsorbed NH3(ad) at neighboring sites. These intermediates eventually decompose into N2 and N2O. 3.4.2 Steady-state dynamics studies Based on the analysis of the reaction process of E-R mechanism and L-H mechanism, the kinetic equations of SCR reaction and NSCR reaction can be approximately described as (See SI for a detailed derivation–n) : (16) k SCR = d [ N 2 ] dt = k E - R [ NO ( g ) ] + k L - H = k 1 [ NH 2 ] [ NO ( g ) ] + k 5 [ M ( n - 1 ) + - O - NO - NH 3 ] (17) k NSCR = d [ N 2 O ] dt = k NSCR - ER + k NSCR - LH = k 4 [ NH 2 ] [ M n + = O ] + k 6 [ M ( n - 1 ) + - O - NO 2 - NH 3 ] (18) k NO = k E–R[NO(g)] + k L–H + k NSCR The experimental findings demonstrate a strong linear correlation between the reduction rate of NO and the concentration of NO in the gas phase. Concurrently, despite increases in the concentration of NO in the gas phase, the formation rate of N2O remains relatively constant. This observation suggests that the rate of N2O formation is essentially unaffected by the concentration of NO in the gaseous state (Fig. 12(b) ). Through linear regression analysis of the data presented in Fig. 12(a), the pertinent kinetic parameters of the MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalyst can be derived. Notably, it becomes evident that the formation rate of N2 exhibits a linear relationship with the concentration of NO in the gas phase, while the formation rate of N2O remains independent of the concentration of NO in the gas phase. Consequently, the selectivity towards N2 gradually increases with rising NO concentration. Both the rate constants k SCR-ER and k SCR-LH exhibit an increase with rising temperature (Table 3 ). The SCR reaction on MnCo-CMSMS@0.05GO is enhanced by both the E-R and L-H mechanisms. As shown in Fig. 13 , the E-R and L-H mechanisms contribute to the SCR reaction, with their relative contributions depending on the reaction temperature. The contributions of the E-R and L-H mechanisms to NO x conversion vary with temperature, directly influencing catalyst selectivity and byproduct formation. At 120 °C, both mechanisms contribute equally, where NH3 and NO can react via surface-adsorbed active sites (L-H mechanism) or through a gas-phase reaction pathway (E-R mechanism). However, as the temperature increases, the E-R mechanism gradually becomes dominant, with surface oxygen species playing a crucial role in this process. This shift may be attributed to the enhanced activity of surface oxygen species and the increased NH3 oxidation capacity of the MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalyst. The L-H mechanism is characterized by the preferential formation of nitrate (NO3 –) intermediates on the catalyst surface, which may incompletely react with NH3 at low temperatures, leading to N2O formation. In contrast, the E-R mechanism involves NH3 primarily in an adsorbed state (NH3(ad)), where it is oxidized by active oxygen species (O2 or O–). Consequently, when the E-R mechanism dominates, NH3 oxidation is enhanced, potentially increasing N2O byproduct formation. Comparatively, when the L-H mechanism is dominant, N2O is mainly generated through the nitrate pathway and excessive NH3 oxidation. By optimizing the GO loading, the activity of surface oxygen species can be effectively regulated to balance the contributions of the E-R and L-H mechanisms. This strategy enhances NO x removal efficiency while reducing N2O selectivity, providing new insights into the development of highly efficient and low-byproduct SCR catalysts. 4 Conclusions The efficient preparation of melamine sponge modified with graphene oxide (MnCo-MS@GO) yields a catalyst exhibiting exceptional SCR performance, characterized by high catalytic activity, N2 selectivity, and resilience to water and sulfur. The modification of graphene oxide, achieved without necessitating high-temperature calcination, notably enhances the catalyst's regeneration capability. Even after repeated washing with water, the catalyst maintains its integrity and flexibility over five cycles of reuse. A comparison between MnCo-MS and MnCo-MS@GO highlights the crucial role of graphene oxide doping as a bridging agent between the melamine sponge and the metal component. Graphene is deposited onto the surface of the melamine sponge scaffold, forming covalent bonds with the metal's electronic states, thereby bolstering the binding affinity between graphene and metal while facilitating the uniform dispersion of metal active species. The functional groups present on the surface of graphene oxide serve as redox mediators, augmenting the content of active metal components. Simultaneously, they enhance the material's surface electron transfer capacity, facilitating the migration of active species. The analysis of MnCo-MS@0.05GO through steady-state kinetic assessment reveals a linear correlation between the rate of N2 generation during the SCR reaction and the concentration of gaseous NO. The L-H and E-R mechanisms govern the formation of N2O during SCR reactions. The L-H mechanism generates N2O mainly through nitrate intermediates and incomplete NH3 reaction at low temperatures. The E-R mechanism enhances NH3 oxidation, potentially increasing N2O formation. Optimizing graphene oxide (GO) loading can balance the contributions of both mechanisms, improving NO x removal efficiency and reducing N2O selectivity. This approach provides insights into designing SCR catalysts with high efficiency and low byproduct formation. coredata.dc:description: The mechanical performance of flexible catalysts remains a significant challenge for industrial applications. In this study, graphene oxide (GO) functions as both a binder and a redox mediator, serving as a crucial “bridge” between metal species and the organic foam, thereby substantially enhancing NO x conversion efficiency. Catalytic activity tests demonstrate that the GO-modified MnCo-MS@0.05GO catalyst achieves a NO x conversion rate exceeding 95%. The incorporation of GO strengthens the adhesion between the organic foam and metal components, increases the surface roughness of the sponge, and ensures the uniform and stable distribution of metal active sites. Additionally, GO enhances the content of effective catalytic species, improves electron transfer efficiency in the selective catalytic reduction reaction, and reduces diffusion resistance. To elucidate the NO reduction mechanism, in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy and transient reaction studies were performed. The results indicate that as the reaction temperature increases, both the Eley-Rideal and Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanisms contribute to promoting the SCR reaction rate.
